name: Strumming Patterns
description: Build strumming fluency from basic downstrokes through syncopated and muted patterns.

steps.name: Down Strums Only
steps.instructions: Hold a G chord. Strum down on every beat — 1, 2, 3, 4. Keep your strumming arm moving in a steady, relaxed motion. Focus on hitting all the strings evenly. Try this on G, then C, then D.
steps.notes: Even simple down strums should sound musical. Accent beat 1 slightly.

steps.name: Down-Up Pattern
steps.instructions: Keep your arm moving in constant down-up motion like a pendulum. Strum: Down-Up-Down-Up on every eighth note. The key insight: your arm never stops moving — you just choose when to make contact with the strings.
steps.notes: Your arm is a metronome. Down on the beat, up on the 'and'.

steps.name: Syncopated Pattern
steps.instructions: The classic folk/rock pattern: Down, Down-Up, Up-Down-Up (D, D-U, U-D-U). In count: 1, 2-and, and-4-and. Your arm still moves constantly — you skip the strum on beat 3 (arm moves down but misses strings).
steps.notes: This is the most common strumming pattern in popular music. Master it and you can play hundreds of songs.

steps.name: Muted Strums (Chucking)
steps.instructions: Hold a chord but lightly release pressure with your fretting hand to mute the strings on specific beats. Play: Strum-Mute-Strum-Mute (strum on 1 and 3, mute/chuck on 2 and 4). This creates a percussive rhythm.
steps.notes: The muted strum should sound like a crisp 'chk'. Don't lift your fingers completely off the strings.

steps.name: Apply to a Song
steps.instructions: Pick a song with a simple chord progression (try G-Em-C-D or Am-F-C-G). Apply the strumming patterns you just practiced. Start with the syncopated pattern, then add muted strums for flavor.
steps.notes: Music is about feel. Listen to the song and match your strumming to its energy.
